Women's Executive Club | LinkedIn Skip to main content LinkedIn Top Content People Learning Jobs Games Sign in Join now Women's Executive Club Think Tanks Accelerating executive women‚Äôs success Follow View 1 employee Report this company About us Women's Executive Club is a private organization for successful women leaders of $ million to multi-billion dollar companies, of various industries and geographies. 
The Club brings together such high-achieving CEO's, top professionals, and entrepreneurs for peer advisory groups so that, by working together, they can create new possibilities for growth, enhanced leadership, and accelerated next successes - easier, faster, and better than alone. 

APPLY now to explore Club membership and to determine if it's a mutual fit. Apply at: www.WomensEC.com 

CONTACT US to learn more. 
www.WomensEC.com/contact 
Email: president@WomensEC.com 
Phone: (913) 449-4996 Website https://www.WomensEC.com External link for Women's Executive Club Industry Think Tanks Company size 2-10 employees Type Privately Held Specialties Women's Network, Strategic Business Connections, Best Practices & Resources Sharing, Peer Advisory Group, Executive Network, Women Business Owners Peer Advisory Groups, Women Leaders, Women's C-Suite Alliance, Mastermind Groups, Partner Level Professionals Exchange, and Women in Biz Employees at Women's Executive Club Deborah Knight Founder & CEO, Women's Executive Club See all employees Updates Women's Executive Club 617 followers 2mo Edited Report this post Are you a new or existing CEO, do you aspire to be a C-suite executive, or are you expanding your company globally? Then join us for insights from Black & Veatch global C-suite executive, Michelle Hartman. Member event June 26th. (Black & Veatch, not Veach - typo below). Apply for WEC at www.WomensEC.com 10 Like Comment Share Women's Executive Club 617 followers 6mo Report this post Happy International Women's Day from the Women's Executive Club! 

Empowering ambitious women everywhere to new heights of success. Join us! 3 Like Comment Share Women's Executive Club 617 followers 6mo Report this post Calling All Ambitious Women in Business!

Are you a driven leader looking to connect with other powerful women? The Women‚Äôs Executive Club (WEC) is a thriving network of CEOs, top executives, and entrepreneurs leading businesses from $1M to multi-billion dollars.

 * Build meaningful connections
 * Gain strategic insights in exclusive Peer Advisory Groups
 * Collaborate, grow, and thrive with like-minded women

Join a community that empowers you to elevate your success. Are you ready to take your leadership to the next level? 

Check out our updated website: https://www.womensec.com/ #WomenInBusiness #Leadership #Networking #WomenExecutives 3 Like Comment Share Women's Executive Club 617 followers 8mo Report this post A new year of possibilities... What will you create? 

Want help making your dreams a reality, then check out the Women's Executive Club.  

Our next cohort starts the end of January. 

Curious? Apply and learn more at www.WomensEC.com #newyear #2025 #womenleaders #entrepreneurs #womeninbiz #womeninbusiness #womanowned #dreamlife #liveyourdreams #ladyboss #femaleleaders #womanceo #womenceos #bosslady 3 2 Comments Like Comment Share Women's Executive Club 617 followers 8mo Report this post Step into the new year with confidence at Women's Executive Club! Enrollment now open for January mastermind. 

Start the new year strong with insights, feedback, and expertise of successful executives and entrepreneurs, aka: YOUR Personal Board of Advisors!

Soar to new heights and next-level successes in your business and career in 2025, fueled by the genius, experiences, networks, and camaraderie of high-achieving women at the Women's Executive Club. 

Apply now for January mastermind at: www.WomensEC.com Let's go! #womeninbiz #femaleceos #womeninbusiness #womanleader #bosslady #womanexecutive #womanowned #ladyboss #womanceo 2 1 Comment Like Comment Share Women's Executive Club 617 followers 8mo Report this post Crush your goals in 2025! Join the waitlist for January Mastermind cohort. You'll be among the first to be considered for admission to WEC mastermind in January. Enrollment opens next week. 

In WEC mastermind, gain confidential feedback and exchange ideas with accomplished executives and successful entrepreneurs. Tap into collective genius, expertise, experience, and networks of high-achieving peers to accelerate your next-level success in 2025! 

Sign up for waitlist at: www.WomensEC.com Cheers to you and your next-level success! #womenleaders #womeninbiz #womeninbusiness #womanowned #womenceos #femaleceo #ladyboss #bosslady 2 Like Comment Share Women's Executive Club 617 followers 9mo Report this post Treat yourself to Women's Executive Club exclusive membership. Add the Club to your shopping list to catapult your next level success. 1 4 Comments Like Comment Share Women's Executive Club 617 followers 10mo Report this post The right connections to catapult your next-level success! Join us for our next executive mastermind on Oct. 30th. Apply now at: www.WomensEC.com #womenceos #womanCEO #Womanleader #ladyboss #femaleleader #womanowned #womeninbiz 2 Like Comment Share Women's Executive Club 617 followers 11mo Report this post Our mastermind meeting this week: Connections to T.V. producers, getting product into high-end boutiques, and business growth strategies were shared. 

These are a few examples of what our peer groups can do to increase your visibility and catapult your success.

Women's Executive Club = Your own personal board of advisors. 

Gain the collective expertise, experience, intelligence, and networks of high-achieving women at Women's Executive Club.

Facilities - Chiefland Golf & Country Club Skip to main content Skip to footer Chiefland Golf & Country Club Home Course Course Details Rates Book a Tee Time Events Tournaments Upcoming Events Facilities Membership Contact Contact Us Directions and Address Facilities Pro Shop Chiefland Golf & Country Club¬†offers the best in equipment and apparel to compliment your game. Stop by our fully-stocked Pro Shop before or after your round and browse through name brands. Our friendly staff will help you make start times, ¬†rent golf carts, sign up for club storage, and register you and your guests before each round of golf. ¬†An excellent selection of golf clubs and related merchandise are sold in the golf shop and golf lessons are available. Contact the Pro Shop for assistance, or to make an appointment for lessons. Practice Facilities Chiefland Golf & Country Club offers chipping and putting areas, and is the perfect place to improve your short game. Chiefland is also equipped with a driving range and PGA staff available for lessons. What better way to take your game to the next level this year? Make time to perfect your swing and improve your golf game today. Just contact our pro shop to speak with our professional staff and schedule your lesson. Bar The bar is the perfect way to end your round at Chiefland. Unwind with your favorite beverage from our fully stocked bar while you relax enjoying the natural surroundings. Footer Weather CHIEFLAND WEATHER Visit Us Chiefland Golf + Country Club 9650 NW 115th St Chiefland, FL 32626 Follow Us Follow us on Facebook Follow us on Twitter Follow us on Instagram Find us on Yelp Contact Us Phone: (352) 493-2375 Email: chieflandgolfcountryclub@yahoo.com Privacy & Cookies: This site uses cookies. By continuing to use this website, you agree to their use. About Us - Woman's Club of Coconut Grove (305) 446-2909 Contact Form info@wccg1891.org Woman's Club About Us Our Mission Board of Directors Awards & Accolades Club History (Lest We Forget) Newsletters GFWC GFWC GFWC FL District 11 Committees Young Artists‚Äô Gallery (YAG) Arts & Culture Community Life Education Environment Historic Preservation Bingo (Hospitality) Human Trafficking Awareness & Prevention (HTAP) Volunteer Activities Store Donate Events Event Listing Event Calendar Newsletter Photo Gallery Membership Member Login Pay Membership Dues Membership Application Contact About Us The Woman's Club of Coconut Grove The Woman‚Äôs Club was initially founded in 1891 and dedicated to the enrichment of our community through the promotion of public welfare, education, civic improvement, historic preservation and advancement of the arts and culture; while fostering good fellowship among its members. The Club has served as a social, educational and cultural center throughout its history. Historically, the Club was - and is - a place where women (and men) came together to forge relationships and create a sense of community through service activities. Our History In 1891, five years before Miami became a city, Flora McFarlane and the women of Coconut Grove formed the Housekeeper‚Äôs Club, a small group of women joined forces to become what we now recognize as the Woman‚Äôs Club of Coconut Grove. As a female homesteader and teacher, Flora McFarlane, was keenly aware of the isolation and loneliness of the pioneer woman. As a result, she invited women in the community to take part in weekly gatherings. Her goal was ‚Äúto bring together the housekeepers of our little settlement by spending two hours a week in companionship and study.‚Äù By working together their pioneering spirit built a community. Their motto was ‚Äúlend a hand.‚Äù Members of the Club have provided service to the community and support for each other for more than 150 years. Their first major project raised funds to build the Sunday School Chapel in 1894; which eventually became Plymouth Congregational Church. Plymouth Congregational Church The Club was known as the cultural center of early Coconut Grove, hosting theatrical performances, literary readings, musical entertainment and parties. Members were engaged in the Everglades conservation, saving Paradise Key consequently, forming a core group of key preservationists as the nucleus of Everglades National Park activists. In later years, the Club provided financial aid for local and national organizations like Casa Valentina, Cancer Survivors, Virrick Public Library, the Hacienda Girls‚Äô Ranch, Canine Companions, and Heifer International. Additionally, the Club has sponsored the Learn-To-Swim program at the Virrick Pool that taught hundreds of West Grove children to swim. Its Young Artists‚Äô Gallery scholarship program has (and continues to) provided exhibition opportunities and grants for Miami-Dade High School students with well over $4,500 in awards, grants, and scholarships. Over the years the Woman‚Äôs Club has proven to be a progressive and forward-thinking safe haven for women to come together, build relationships, and create a sense of community through their civic service activities. HISTORICAL TIMELINE OF ROYAL PALM PARK 1916-2016 In the 1880s and 1890s many Naturalists explored the Everglades. South Florida was the honeymoon destination for Kirk and Mary Munroe. The Housekeepers Club, founded in 1891, even hosted the 10th Annual Convention of the Florida Federation of Woman‚Äôs Clubs in their Coconut Grove clubhouse on January 25, 1905 at which Mary and Edith Gifford presented a resolution to conserve the Royal Palm Hammock as a State Reservation. In 1914, May Mann Jennings became president of the Federation and took further action to push through the conservation legislation. In 1915, an act of legislation granted the Florida Federation Royal Palm State Park. Without funding, the Florida Clubwomen raised sufficient dollars, dimes, nickels and pennies to make the hammock ready for the dedication in November of 1916. The Legislative Act stipulated that the Federation must improve, beautify, and maintain the state park. Often forgotten, this bit of history is a good reminder of the collective woman‚Äôs voice during a time when women had no voice, vote, or rights. 32 years later, the women of Florida remained steadfast in their resolve and maintained the state park despite brush fires, the 1916 Hurricane, WWI, the Great Depression and World War II. Simultaneously, the Federation actively pursued the formation of a National Park. Finally in 1947, The Federation deeded their adored Royal Palm State Park to the Everglades National Park. One hundred years ago, May Jennings dedicated the Park to the people of Florida and their children forever. As a result, historical boards were developed in conjunction with the Everglades National Park in honor of its 100th Birthday Celebration. Save the Birds The Story of Royal Palm State Park began with the protection of wildlife. A Dream Come True The first proposal for the preservation of Royal Palm Hammock was seeded at the Woman‚Äôs Club of Coconut Grove in 1905‚Ä¶view the boars. Save the Swamp! In 1840 the Florida State Legislature declared that the Everglades could be repurposed and turned into a profitable farmland to learn about the history of the effort to drain the Everglades. Become a Member Our Partnership with the Women‚Äôs Suffrage National Monument Join us in funding the first U.S. monument dedicated to Women‚Äôs History Support Today An International Organization with Global Impact Learn More Who we are With more than 63,000 members in affiliated clubs in every state , the District of Columbia, and more than a dozen countries, GFWC members work in their own communities to support the arts, preserve natural resources, advance education, promote healthy lifestyles, and encourage civic involvement, issues related to domestic and sexual violence awareness/prevention, and advocating for children. learn more OUR IMPACT General Federation of Women‚Äôs Clubs members vary in age, talents, location, background, and profession, but are united in their dedication to actively improve the lives of others. 63,000+ members in affiliated clubs in every state 2,600 existing volunteer clubs across the globe 130+ founded in 1890, GFWC has over a century of history learn more WHRC: From the Archives September 04, 2025 WHRC: From the Archives A Prize-Winning Centennial Celebration The end of summer means back-to-school season for some‚Ä¶ but in many American communities, it‚Äôs also time for state‚Ä¶ August 07, 2025 WHRC: From the Archives An Ode to Summer: Baking with GFWC The WHRC was lucky enough to have two college interns this summer, Sydney Trager and Riley‚Ä¶ July 03, 2025 WHRC: From the Archives Researching Settlement Work in the Tennessee Federation The WHRC is delighted to offer our first guest blogger, Cate LiaBraaten! Every donation brings us closer to our goal of restoring our Headquarters fa√ßade to its full glory, helping repair the iconic white front-facing exterior walls of GFWC‚Äôs beloved Headquarters buildings. $70,000 77% Make A gift FEATURED CONTENT GFWC International Day of Service The General Federation of Women‚Äôs Clubs (GFWC) is united in its dedication to volunteer community service. The GFWC International Day of Service brings together clubs from around the world to stand united against domestic and sexual violence. Learn about the 2025 GFWC International Day of Service Signature Program: Domestic and Sexual Violence Awareness and Prevention GFWC creates and leads education, public awareness, and service projects for club members and local citizens at the community level; collaborates with national domestic violence networks and organizations; supports existing activities and established programs; advocates for victims and survivors; and provides educational opportunities to survivors. GFWC aims to be a powerful voice for victims and survivors. The WHRC documents the social and political contributions of GFWC clubwomen from 1890 to the present through the GFWC archives and related special collections. September is Library Card Sign-Up Month, so today we're asking you about your favorite public library benefit. How do you use your library card? Your WHRC Librarian is on vacation with friends this week, but the beauty of a library card is she can borrow digital books even though she's out of town. Your public library might offer book clubs, craft workshops, yoga classes, children's story time, lectures, study rooms, printer and internet access, audiovisual materials, tax forms, sheet music, and more. They might provide access to newspapers, genealogy databases, language learning software, and other resources without needing a personal subscription. Some library systems offer free admission to local parks and museums. In DC, patrons can use the 3D printer, or reserve time in the recording studio. My hometown library supplied the community with Covid tests and masks throughout the toughest years of the pandemic. A friend from LA (who just signed up for her digital library card this morning) can borrow musical instruments when she gets back to California. And many library systems across the country are the repository for our member clubs' historical archives, making them accessible for researchers and preserving them for the future. So tell us, what's your favorite library card benefit? Is your club promoting Library Card Sign-up Month? Let us know in the comments! üì∑A group of vacationing, book-themed-t-shirt-wearing women holding their library cards, with your WHRC Librarian on the right. #LibraryCardSignUpMonth ‚Ä¶ See More See Less 13 hours ago What club activity do you have planned for Alzheimer's Association Awareness month? Next Monday, September 8th, is International Literacy Day. Literacy has been a key focus of GFWC, and our member clubs, since the 19th century: helping every member of our communities, old and young, reach their potential through reading skills and comprehension. During the 1962-1964 administration of GFWC President Margaret Long Arnold, we even sponsored the publication of a manual (with the help of experts at the US Office of Education, forerunner of the Department of Education). Specifically aimed at volunteers, we believed it would help our members dive into "the fight against illiteracy." In a letter urging clubs to purchase the book, Arnold wrote, "You will see that there is a job for all club members at all levels‚Ä¶ This is an important project upon which we have embarked to help our fellow citizens help themselves. It is a giant step in the right direction and we must not let our footsteps falter as we face the many problems that will have to be surmounted." üìí"Your club can spark the fight against illiteracy!" Flyer for the new book "Teaching Adults the Literacy Skills," 1963. PRO 1962-1964 f20 #InternationalLiteracyDay #ClubwomenInHistory #LivingTheVolunteerSpirit ‚Ä¶ See More See Less 1 week ago It‚Äôs WHRC Wednesday! To round out our look at the letters received by the GFWC Resolutions Committee in the lead-up to the 1914 convention, here is one of the odder letters in that archival file: an urgent plea from inventor Laura A. McLain of Newark, Ohio, to Jane Addams (yes, that Jane Addams) regarding the dangers of unguarded hatpins. Mrs. McLain received a patent for her new and improved ‚Äúhat-pin guard‚Äù in January 1914. Seeing a potential market, or knowing the legislative successes of the Federation (probably both), McLain hoped to persuade attendees of our June 1914 Convention to adopt her invention both in spirit (in the form of a resolution) and in fact (in the form of purchased guards). Her letter claims, ‚Äúthere is no work needed more than to stop the use of the barbarous unprotected hat pin‚Ä¶if there is any reform work needed more than this, I should be glad to know what it is.‚Äù Hatpins could indeed be dangerous, both purposefully ‚Äì see the comments for links regarding the ‚Äúhatpin peril‚Äù of the early 20th century, mostly in relation to women using them for self-defense against harassment ‚Äì and accidentally. But, to be blunt (no hatpin pun intended), there were more pressing items on the GFWC agenda. Sadly for the enterprising Mrs. McLain, it doesn‚Äôt seem that the Convention took this problem seriously enough to offer it as a formal resolution. As for Jane Addams, my suspicion is that she never saw this letter; it was probably delivered to the Chicago hotel where the convention was taking place and redirected to the Resolutions committee. But the fact that a non-member addressed a plea to Addams, as a Chicago representative of GFWC, does speak to her renown as both an activist and a clubwoman. üì∑ First page of McLain's letter to GFWC via Jane Addams, June 9, 1914. (Full text of the letter in the comments.) Resolutions collection, correspondence, 1914 üì∑ Patent no. 1,083,333 granted to Laura A. McLain of Newark, Ohio on January 6, 1914 for a Hat Pin Guard, "a useful and ornamental device which may be slipped over the pointed end of a pin that is projected through the hat to prevent contact of said point with any object." ‚Ä¶ See More See Less 2 weeks ago GFWC proudly commemorates the 1920 certification of the 19th Amendment to the Constitution, granting women the right to vote. For more than 135 years, GFWC has advocated for women's rights and for the needs of children, families, and our local communities in the U.S. and around the world. Thanks to our supporters, we're fighting for families today and working toward a future without Alzheimer's by: ‚Ä¢  Investing $430 million in over 1,150 active research projects in 57 countries. ‚Ä¢  Supporting the nearly 12 million caregivers and the over 7 million Americans living with Alzheimer's with information about care options, caregiver health resources, and digital tools like ALZConnected¬Æ. ‚Ä¢  Giving anyone impacted by this devastating disease somewhere to turn in times of need through our free 24/7 Helpline (800.272.3900). Why We Support St. Jude: Nearly 100,000 members strong, the General Federation of Women`s Clubs is united in its dedication to volunteer community service. While diverse in age, interests, and experiences, all clubwomen are united by a desire to create positive change in their communities. Celebrating more than 125 year of service, GFWC is committed to remain a leading voice in areas where members are active every day. As an organization dedicated to community improvement, they are dedicated to discussing important topics that impact the quality of life for all. The women of the General Federation of Women‚Äôs Clubs (GFWC) have participated in multiple projects that benefit children. Clubwomen have become strong advocates for children by working to: 1) Ensure children are protected from harmful situations 2) Encourage healthy physical and emotional lifestyles 3) Impact policy to improve children‚Äôs lives As exemplified by their tagline "Living the Volunteer Spirit," GFWC clubwomen transform lives each day, not simply with monetary donations, but with hands-on, tangible projects and volunteer efforts that provide immediate impact. With a grassroots approach that often thinks locally but impacts globally, GFWC remains committed to serving as a force for global good. The GFWC is proud to return as National Team for the third year. Long before most military branches opened their doors, women were officially appointed as keepers in the U.S. Lighthouse Service, a proud predecessor to today‚Äôs Coast Guard. These trailblazing women safeguarded our shores, guided sailors home through every storm, and rescued numerous boaters in distress, undoubtedly laying the foundation for centuries of female Coast Guard heroes to come. Let‚Äôs celebrate the U.S. Coast Guard and honor the countless women who have served with strength and dedication by supporting the creation of a new national landmark: the National Coast Guard Museum! About Us - Woman's Club of El Paso 1400 North Mesa Street El Paso, TX, 79902 (915) 532-6131 About Us The Woman‚Äôs Club of El Paso has a rich and colorful history , and has been a vital force in the community for well over a century. Through the years, the club, its founders, and members have been a part of many firsts ; however, we feel the best has yet to be written! Anchored in our historic clubhouse, as a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization, we meet monthly to offer educational and cultural opportunities for the enjoyment of our members, as well as plan and execute various fundraisers to maintain our building, and positively impact the community in a variety of ways. Our beautiful clubhouse has been the center for a variety of special events through the years, including recitals, lectures and melodramas, just to name a few. When not in use by The Woman‚Äôs Club, it can be rented for special events. As members, we enjoy working together to maintain our historic clubhouse and improve conditions in our community. Membership is open to all women (without regard to race, creed or color) who support the mission of the Woman‚Äôs Club of El Paso. Membership is by invitation. Please contact us at wcoep@att.net or call 915-532-6131 for additional information. Through our auxiliaries, our members have additional opportunities for enrichment and developing friendships as they learn, and work together. Auxiliaries and The Junior Woman‚Äôs Club: The Arts & Crafts Study Club meets the second Monday of each month at 9:30 a.m., beginning in September through May. The purpose of the Arts and Crafts is to further the interest in the study and creation of various phases of Art. The Book Club meets the second Tuesday of each month at 10:00 a.m., beginning in September through May. The purpose of The Book Club is to further the enjoyment, reading and reviewing of books. The Junior Woman‚Äôs Club of El Paso , an associate organization, founded in 1934, has members devoting their time and energy to local charitable organizations and social service agencies through community service projects and fundraising events.
